column1: Bismarck () is the capital of the U.S. state of North Dakota and the county seat of Burleigh County.  It is the second-most populous city in North Dakota after Fargo. The city's population was estimated in 2019 at 73
column3: while its metropolitan population was 128
column5: Forbes magazine ranked Bismarck as the seventh fastest-growing small city in the United States.Bismarck was founded by European-Americans in 1872 on the east bank of the Missouri River. It has been North Dakota's capital city since 1889
column6: when the state was created from the Dakota Territory and admitted to the Union.

column1: Bismarck is across the river from Mandan
column2: named after a historic Native American tribe of the area. The two cities make up the core of the Bismarck–Mandan Metropolitan Statistical Area.
the tallest building in the state
column3: is in central Bismarck. The state government employs more than 4
column4: 600 in the city.  As a hub of retail and health care
column5: Bismarck is the economic center of south-central North Dakota and north-central South Dakota.

column2: present-day central North Dakota was inhabited by indigenous peoples
column3: who created successive cultures. The historic Mandan Native American tribe occupied the area long before Europeans arrived. The Hidatsa name for Bismarck is mirahacii arumaaguash ("Place of the tall willows"); the Arikara name is ituhtaáwe [itUhtaáwe].In 1872 European Americans founded a settlement at what was then called Missouri Crossing
column4: so named because the Lewis and Clark Expedition crossed the river there on their exploration of the Louisiana Purchase in 1804–1806. It had been an area of Mandan settlement. Later the new town was called Edwinton
column5: after Edwin Ferry Johnson
column6: engineer-in-chief for the Northern Pacific Railway. Its construction of railroads in the territory attracted workers and settlers.

column2: the Northern Pacific Railway renamed the city to Bismarck
column3: in honor of German chancellor Otto von Bismarck. It is the only US state capital named for a foreign statesman.  Railroad officials hoped to attract German immigrant settlers to the area and German investment in the railroad. The discovery of gold in the nearby Black Hills of South Dakota the following year was a greater impetus for growth. Thousands of miners came to the area
column4: encroaching on what the Lakota considered sacred territory and leading to heightened tensions with the Native Americans. Bismarck became a freight-shipping center on the "Custer Route" from the Black Hills. In 1883 Bismarck was designated as the capital of the Dakota Territory
column5: and in 1889 as the state capital of the new state of North Dakota.

column4: of which 30.85 square miles (79.90 km2) is land and 0.38 square miles (0.98 km2) is water.

column1: The city has developed around downtown Bismarck
column2: the center of historic development. It is distinctive because the city's major shopping center
column3: Kirkwood Mall
column4: is in the city center rather than in the suburbs. Several other major retail stores are in the vicinity of Kirkwood Mall
column5: which was developed near the Bismarck Civic Center. The two Bismarck hospitals
column6: CHI St. Alexius Medical Center and Sanford Health (previously Medcenter One Health Systems) are both downtown. The streets are lined with small stores and restaurants.

column1: Much recent commercial and residential growth has taken place in the city's northern section
column2: largely because of expanding retail centers. Among the shopping centers in northern Bismarck are Gateway Fashion Mall
column3: Northbrook Mall
column5: and the Pinehurst Square "power center" mall.

column1: The North Dakota State Capitol complex is just north of downtown Bismarck. The 19-story Art Deco capitol is the tallest building in the state
column2: at a height of 241.75 feet (73.69 m). The capitol building towers over the city's center and is easily seen from 20 miles (32 km) away on a clear day. Completed during the Great Depression in 1934
column3: it replaced a capitol building that burned to the ground in 1930. The capitol grounds encompass the North Dakota Heritage Center
column5: the North Dakota Governor's Residence
column7: and the Liberty Memorial Building. The North Dakota State Penitentiary is in eastern Bismarck.

column2: named after the Art Deco Cathedral of the Holy Spirit
column3: is an historic neighborhood near downtown Bismarck. Some homes in this neighborhood date to the 1880s
column4: although many were built in the first decades of the 20th century. At times
column5: the city has proposed widening the streets in the neighborhood to improve traffic flow. Many residents object because such a project would require the removal of many of the towering American elms which line the streets. These have escaped the elm disease that destroyed street canopies of trees in eastern cities.

column1: After the completion of Garrison Dam in 1953 by the Army Corps of Engineers
column3: the floodplain of the Missouri River became a more practical place for development. Significant residential and commercial building has taken place in this area on the south side of the city. The Upper Missouri River is still subject to seasonal flooding.

column1: Situated in the middle of the Great Plains
column2: between the geographic centers of the United States and Canada
column3: Bismarck displays a highly variable four-season humid continental climate (Köppen Dwa). Bismarck's climate is characterized by cold and dry
column5: and hot
column6: humid summers. Thunderstorms occur in spring and summer
column7: but much of the rest of the year is dry.

column1: The warmest month in Bismarck is July
column3: with typically wide variations between day and night. The coldest month is January
column4: with a 24-hour average of 13 °F (−10.6 °C). Precipitation peaks from May to September and is rather sparse in the winter months. Winter snowfall is typically light to moderate
column5: occurring with the passage of frontal systems; major storms are rare.

column1: Bismarck operates under the city commission style of municipal government. Citizens elect five at-large city commissioners
column2: which means they must generally command a majority of the electorate. The president of the city commission fills the office of mayor of the city. The current mayor of Bismarck is Steve Bakken. The city commission meets every second and fourth Tuesday of each month.

column1: Bismarck has a large park system and an extensive network of exercise trails. The Bismarck Parks and Recreation District
column3: operates many parks
column5: and several golf courses within the city. The World War I Memorial Building
column6: which is listed on the National Register of Historic Places and operated by the recreation district
column7: serves as a community gymnasium and was recognized by a 100 Cities 100 Memorials grant in 2018.The Parks and Recreation District operates roughly 2
column8: 300 acres (930 ha) of public parkland. Sertoma Park stretches more than 3 miles (4.8 km) along the banks of the Missouri River. Within the park are several miles of biking trails and the Dakota Zoo.

column1: There are five golf courses in Bismarck: four 18-hole courses (Apple Creek Country Club

column1: One of the main tourism attractions of the Bismarck area is Fort Abraham Lincoln State Park
column2: 7 miles (11 km) south of neighboring Mandan. It contains the partial reconstruction of Fort Abraham Lincoln
column3: the headquarters of the 7th Cavalry and last command of General George Armstrong Custer before the Battle of the Little Bighorn (also known as the Battle of the Greasy Grass). The park includes On-a-Slant Village
column4: a partially rebuilt earth lodge village once occupied by people of the historic Mandan tribe. Guided tours of both sites are offered in the summertime. There are also a museum on park history
column5: nature trails
column6: and a campground.Hunting and fishing are popular in the area
column9: and waterfowl. Fishing is a year-round sport on the Missouri River bordering Bismarck
column10: and there are public docks on the river. From north to south
column11: there is a dock at the Port of Bismarck
column12: from which the Lewis and Clark passenger riverboat plies the Missouri; Fox Island Landing
column13: about a half mile southwest of Riverwood Golf Course; and the Bismarck Dock at General Sibley Park
column14: which has a boat ramp and picnic facilities.

column1: Bismarck is a regional center for health care. The city has two hospitals: CHI St. Alexius Medical Center (285-bed) and Sanford Health (238-bed). When it was opened in 1885
column2: St. Alexius was the first hospital in Dakota Territory and the Catholic facility is the oldest health care provider in the state of North Dakota. St. Alexius and Medcenter One have joined forces to form the Bismarck Cancer Center.  Medcenter One was founded in 1908 as Bismarck Evangelical Hospital. In 1955 it was renamed as Bismarck Hospital
column3: renamed again in 1984 to MedCenter One
column4: and in 2012 became part of the Sanford Health system.

column1: PrintBismarck is served by the Bismarck Tribune
column2: the city's daily newspaper.  Established in 1873
column3: the paper is the oldest continuously operating business in the city. The Tribune is the official newspaper of the city of Bismarck
column5: and the state of North Dakota. The daily newspapers of other major cities in North Dakota are also available at area newsstands.

column1: The Capital Area Transit System (CAT) began operations in May 2004. This public bus system is operated by the Bis-Man Transit Board and has eleven routes throughout Bismarck and Mandan
column2: Monday-Saturday. Bis-Man Transit also operates a para-transit service for senior citizens and people with disabilities.Bismarck Municipal Airport is south of the city. It has the largest passenger volume in western North Dakota and the second highest within the state. The airport is served by United Express
column3: Allegiant Air
column5: American Airlines
column6: and Frontier Airlines. A new $15 million terminal opened in May 2005. The previous terminal was built in the mid-1960s and expanded in the mid-1970s. After a windstorm collapsed part of the roof connecting the expanded terminal to the original building
column7: officials decided to demolish the entire complex and build the new terminal.

column1: The BNSF Railway runs east–west through the city. The railway was originally integral to the growth of Bismarck and Mandan. Today it is used for freight. Due to restructuring in the railroad industry
column2: there has not been passenger train service in Bismarck since Amtrak's North Coast Hiawatha service ended in 1979. The closest Amtrak station is in Minot
column3: north of Bismarck
column4: which is served by the Empire Builder.

column1: Two federal highways pass through Bismarck. Interstate 94 runs east–west through the city. The north–south U.S. Route 83 merges in north Bismarck with Interstate 94 and runs east for roughly 25 miles (40 km) before turning south.
High school and college sports are the main feature of the local athletics landscape. The athletic teams at the three public Bismarck high schools
column3: Century High School

column8: respectively. The athletic teams at St. Mary's Central High School

column11: and both compete in the National Junior College Athletic Association. The teams at the University of Mary are The Marauders and compete in the Northern Sun Intercollegiate Conference.  Bismarck has an American Legion baseball team called the Governors.

column2: the accent is on high school and college football. There are spirited rivalries among the several high schools in the area. The University of Mary added the sport in 1988. column1: The Bismarck Bobcats hockey team of the North American Hockey League is made up of junior players (age twenty and younger

column3: claiming their first-ever Robertson Cup title in 2010.

column1: The Dakota Wizards of the NBA Development League was formerly based in Bismarck.  The Wizards' first season took place in 1995 in the International Basketball Association. They were the 2006–07 champions of the NBA D-League
